title: Karoline_Leavitt
extract: Karoline Claire Leavitt is an American political aide and government official who has been serving as the 36th White House press secretary since January 2025 under President Donald Trump. She is the youngest White House press secretary in history.
text:
{{Short description|American political aide (born 1997)}}
{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}}
{{Use American English|date=November 2024}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2019}}
{{Infobox officeholder
| name                = Karoline Leavitt
| image               = Karoline Leavitt at her first Press Conference in 2025 (cropped).jpg
| alt                 = 
| caption             = Leavitt at her first White House press conference on January 28, 2025
| order               = 36th
| office              = White House Press Secretary
| president           = [[Donald Trump]]
| term_start          = January 20, 2025
| term_end            = 
| predecessor         = [[Karine Jean-Pierre]]
| successor           = 
| birth_name          = Karoline Claire Leavitt
| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1997|8|24}}
| birth_place         = [[Atkinson, New Hampshire]], U.S.
| death_date          = 
| death_place         = 
| party               = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]
| spouse              = Nicholas Riccio
| children            = 1
| education           = [[Saint Anselm College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
}}
'''Karoline Claire Leavitt''' (born August 24, 1997)<ref name="Baby in a hot car">{{cite news |title=Birthday of the Day: Karoline Leavitt, White House assistant press secretary |date=24 August 2020 |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/24/playbook-birthday-karoline-leavitt-400593 |access-date=26 June 2024|work=Politico |archive-date=26 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240626013621/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/24/playbook-birthday-karoline-leavitt-400593 |url-status=live}}</ref> is an American political aide and government official who has been serving as the 36th [[White House Press Secretary|White House press secretary]] since January 2025 under President [[Donald Trump]]. She is the youngest White House press secretary in history.<ref name=":4" />

Leavitt was a presidential writer and assistant [[press secretary]] during the [[First presidency of Donald Trump|first Donald Trump administration]]. In 2022, she ran for the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] in [[2022 United States House of Representatives elections in New Hampshire|New Hampshire's 1st district]], winning the Republican nomination before losing in the general election to Democratic incumbent [[Chris Pappas (American politician)|Chris Pappas]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Cohen |first=Li |date=2022-09-14 |title=25-year-old Karoline Leavitt becomes first Republican Gen Z congressional nominee after winning New Hampshire primary - CBS News |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/karoline-leavitt-new-hampshire-primary-win-first-republican-gen-z-congressional-candidate/ |access-date=2024-06-29 |website=www.cbsnews.com |language=en-US}}</ref> She was a spokesperson for [[MAGA Inc.]], a pro-Trump [[Super PAC]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-11-16 |title=Trump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt named as next White House press secretary |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/trump-campaign-spokesperson-karoline-leavitt-named-as-next-white-house-press-secretary |access-date=2025-01-30 |website=PBS News |language=en-us}}</ref> and she served as the national press secretary for [[Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign|Donald Trump's 2024 presidential campaign]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Singman |first1=Brooke |date=3 April 2023 |title=Karoline Leavitt to join Trump super PAC as spokeswoman |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/karoline-leavitt-join-trump-super-pac-spokeswoman |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240626041534/https://www.foxnews.com/politics/karoline-leavitt-join-trump-super-pac-spokeswoman |archive-date=26 June 2024 |access-date=26 June 2024 |website=[[Fox News]]}}</ref>

== Early life and education ==
Karoline Claire Leavitt<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://voterrecords.com/voter/114097454/karoline-leavitt|title=Karoline Claire Leavitt from Washington, District Of Columbia|website=VoterRecords.com}}</ref> was born in [[Atkinson, New Hampshire]], where she was raised in the [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] faith.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last=Burt |first=Bill |date=November 28, 2020|title=Meet the assistant press secretary |url=https://www.eagletribune.com/news/merrimack_valley/meet-the-assistant-press-secretary/article_cf79da8f-fed1-5769-99c4-7adc1aa72c6f.html |access-date=June 29, 2024 |website=[[Eagle-Tribune]] |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201129015555/https://www.eagletribune.com/news/merrimack_valley/meet-the-assistant-press-secretary/article_cf79da8f-fed1-5769-99c4-7adc1aa72c6f.html |archive-date= 29 November 2020}}</ref> Her family owned an ice cream shop and a used truck dealership in [[Plaistow, New Hampshire]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" /> She attended [[Central Catholic High School (Massachusetts)|Central Catholic High School]] in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]]. She then attended [[Saint Anselm College]]<ref name="Archives of Women's Political
trending_reason: The Karoline Leavitt article is likely trending on Wikipedia due to her recent appointment as the White House Press Secretary and her historic status as the youngest individual to hold that position.

title: Bog_butter
extract: Bog butter is an ancient waxy substance found buried in peat bogs, particularly in Ireland and Scotland. Likely an old method of making and preserving butter, some tested lumps of bog butter were made of dairy, while others were made of animal fat.
text:
{{short description|Ancient substance found in peat bogs}}
[[File: Bog butter.JPG|thumb|Bog butter made in 2012 for the [[Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery]].]]
[[File: Bog butter from A Descriptive Catalogue of the Antiquities in the Museum of the Royal Irish Academy 1857.png|thumb|upright|Bog butter from ''A Descriptive Catalogue of the Antiquities in the Museum of the [[Royal Irish Academy]]'', 1857]]

'''Bog butter''' is an ancient [[wax]]y substance found buried in [[peat]] [[bog]]s, particularly in Ireland and Scotland. Likely an old method of making and preserving [[Butter#Middle Ages|butter]], some tested lumps of bog butter were made of dairy, while others were made of animal fat.<ref name=sto269>{{cite web |url=http://www.show.me.uk/site/news/STO269.html |title=Bog Butter Mystery Solved? |date=2004-04-02 |accessdate=2010-04-13 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719140902/http://www.show.me.uk/site/news/STO269.html |archivedate=2011-07-19 }}</ref>

==History==
Bog butter is found buried inside some sort of wooden container, such as [[bucket]]s, [[keg]]s, [[barrel]]s, dishes and [[butter churn]]s. It is of animal origin, and is also known as '''butyrellite'''. Until 2003 [[scientist]]s and [[archaeologist]]s were uncertain of the origin of bog butter. Scientists working at the [[University of Bristol]] discovered that some samples of the "butter" were of [[adipose tissue|adipose]]/[[tallow]] origin while others were of [[dairy]] origin.<ref name=sto269 /><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg18124392.400-bog-butter-test.html |title= Bog Butter test |publisher=[[New Scientist]] |date=2004-03-20 |accessdate=2010-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.culture24.org.uk/places+to+go/south+west/bristol/art20488 |title= Experts Get To The Bottom Of Ancient Bog Butter Mystery |date= 23 March 2004 |first= David |last= Prudames |accessdate= 2010-04-13 |archive-date= 2012-09-29 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120929102631/http://www.culture24.org.uk/places+to+go/south+west/bristol/art20488 |url-status= dead }}</ref>

In Ireland, the practice of burying bog butter dates back to the first century AD, with bog butter found in [[County Meath]].  On 28 April 2011, there were press reports of a find of approximately {{convert|50|kg|lb}} of bog butter in [[Tullamore]], County Offaly.<ref name=Times>{{cite news |title=For Peat's Safe: Bog Butter Unearthed with Turf |work=Irish Times |date=28 Apr 2011 |accessdate=15 Aug 2015 |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/for-peat-s-safe-bog-butter-unearthed-with-turf-1.583009}}</ref> Found in a carved wooden vessel {{convert|30|cm|ft|0}} in diameter and {{convert|60|cm|ft|0}} in height, it was buried at a depth of {{convert|2.3|m|ft}},<ref name=Archaeology>{{cite web |publisher=Irish Archaeology |url=http://irisharchaeology.ie/2011/04/bog-butter/ |title=Bog Butter Find from Co. Offaly |date=28 Apr 2011 |accessdate=15 Aug 2015}}</ref> and still bore a faint smell of dairy.<ref name=Times/> In Scotland, the practice of burying bog butter only dates back to the 2nd or 3rd century AD.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}

Bog butter was produced by interring butter or other fats within a [[peat]] bog after encasement within a wooden container, although augmentation of the latter with a deerskin bladder<ref name=Earwood>{{cite journal |author=Earwood, Caroline |title=Bog Butter: A Two Thousand Year History |journal=The Journal of Irish Archaeology|volume=8 |year=1997 |pages=25–42}}</ref> or layers of plant fibers <ref name=Williams>{{cite journal |author=Williams, James |title=A Sample of Bog Butter from Lachar Moss, Dumfriesshire |journal=Transactions of the Dumfriesshire and Galloway Natural History and Antiquities Society |volume=43 |year=1966}}</ref> was not unusual.  The containers tend to be well-sealed with a convex surface, perhaps to prevent water from pooling and stagnating in direct contact with the packaging and/or contents.<ref name=Reade>{{cite web |author=Reade, Ben |title=Bog Butter: A Gastronomic Perspective |publisher=Nordic Food Lab |date=30 Oct 2013 |accessdate=15 Aug 2015 |url=http://nordicfoodlab.org/blog/2013/10/bog-butter-a-gastronomic-perspective}}</ref>

The original motivations behind the creation of bog butter are unclear. One widespread theory is that [[food product]]s were buried in bogs to hinder spoilage.  Peat bogs, being [[refrigeration|low temperature]], low oxygen, highly acidic environments, have excellent preservative properties.  Experiments conducted by researcher Daniel C. Fisher demonstrated that pathogen and bacterial counts of meat buried in peat bogs for up to two years were comparable to levels found in control samples stored in a modern freezer,<ref name=Pobojewski>{{cite web |author=Pobojewski, Sally |title=Underwater Storage Techniques Preserved Meat for Early Hunters |publisher=The University Record |date=8 May 1995 |accessdate=15 Aug 2015 |url=http://www.ur.umich
trending_reason: The Bog Butter article is likely trending on Wikipedia due to renewed interest in ancient preservation methods and recent archaeological discoveries that shed light on its historical significance and production techniques.

title: Caroline_Kennedy
extract: Caroline Bouvier Kennedy is an American author, diplomat and attorney who served as the United States ambassador to Australia from 2022 to 2024. Kennedy previously served in the Obama administration as the United States ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017. Most of Kennedy's professional life has been in literature, law, politics, education reform, and charity. She is a member of the Kennedy family and the only surviving child of US president John F. Kennedy and First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy.
text:
{{short description|American author and diplomat (born 1957)}} {{About|President John F. Kennedy's daughter|John F. Kennedy Jr.'s wife|Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2021}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Caroline Kennedy | image = Caroline Kennedy, U.S. Ambassador 2.jpg | caption = Official portrait, 2022 | office = [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Australia|United States Ambassador to Australia]] | president = [[Joe Biden]] | term_start = July 25, 2022 | term_end = November 28, 2024 | predecessor = [[Arthur B. Culvahouse Jr.]] | successor = ''Vacant'' | office1 = [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Japan|United States Ambassador to Japan]] | president1 = [[Barack Obama]] | term_start1 = November 19, 2013 | term_end1 = January 18, 2017 | predecessor1 = [[John Roos]] | successor1 = [[Bill Hagerty]] | birth_name = Caroline Bouvier Kennedy | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|11|27}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Edwin Schlossberg]]|July 19, 1986}} | children = {{hlist|[[Rose Schlossberg|Rose]]|[[Tatiana Schlossberg|Tatiana]]|[[Jack Schlossberg|Jack]]}} | parents = {{plainlist| * [[John F. Kennedy]] * [[Jacqueline Kennedy]]}} | relatives = [[Kennedy family]]
[[Bouvier family]] | education = [[Harvard University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|AB]])
[[Columbia University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) | awards = [[Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun]] (2021) | module = {{Listen|pos=center|embed=yes|filename=Opening Statement of Caroline Kennedy at her Confirmation Hearing to be Ambassador to Australia.ogg|title=Kennedy's voice|type=speech|description=Kennedy's opening statement at her confirmation hearing for [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Australia|U.S. ambassador to Australia]]
Recorded April 7, 2022}} }} '''Caroline Bouvier Kennedy''' (born November 27, 1957) is an American author, diplomat and attorney who served as the [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Australia|United States ambassador to Australia]] from 2022 to 2024.https://x.com/USEmbAustralia/status/1861919733219733952?t=5KMthM32vjXdpAgc9DJaHg&s=19 Kennedy previously served in the [[Obama administration]] as the [[United States ambassador to Japan]] from 2013 to 2017.{{cite web| title=United States Embassy To Japan – Former Ambassadors| url=http://jp.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/our-ambassador/former-ambassadors| access-date=May 7, 2017| archive-date=August 24, 2019| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190824062555/https://jp.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/our-ambassador/former-ambassadors/| url-status=dead}} Most of Kennedy's professional life has been in literature, law, [[politics]], education reform, and charity. She is a member of the [[Kennedy family]] and the only surviving child of US president [[John F. Kennedy]] and [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline Kennedy]]. Born in New York City, Kennedy was two years old when her father won the [[1960 United States presidential election|1960 presidential election]] and spent her early childhood years in the [[White House]] during [[Presidency of John F. Kennedy|his presidency]]. She was five years old when [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|he was assassinated]] on November 22, 1963. The following year, she and her younger brother [[John F. Kennedy Jr.]] moved with their mother Jacqueline to the [[Upper East Side]] of [[Manhattan]] where Kennedy continued her education. Kennedy graduated from [[Radcliffe College]] of [[Harvard University]], and later attended [[Columbia Law School]] where she earned a [[Juris Doctor]] degree in 1988. She passed the New York State bar exam the following year. Kennedy worked at Manhattan's [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], where she met her future husband, designer [[Edwin Schlossberg]]. They have three children: [[Rose Schlossberg|Rose]], [[Tatiana Schlossberg|Tatiana]], and [[Jack Schlossberg|Jack]]. Early in the primary race for the [[2008 United States presidential election|2008 presidential election]], Kennedy and her uncle, [[Ted Kennedy]], endorsed Democratic candidate [[Barack Obama]]. She later [[Stump speech (politics)|stumped]] for him in [[Florida]], [[Indiana]], and [[Ohio]], served as co-chair of his [[Democratic Party (United States) vice presidential candidates, 2008|Vice Presidential Search Comm
trending_reason: The Caroline Kennedy article is likely trending on Wikipedia following her recent completion of her term as the United States Ambassador to Australia, which has renewed public interest in her diplomatic legacy and contributions.

title: Carl_McCunn
extract: Carl McCunn was an American wildlife photographer who became stranded in the Alaskan wilderness and eventually committed suicide when he ran out of supplies.
text:
{{short description|American photographer}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2024}}
{{Infobox person
| name                      = Carl McCunn
| image                     = Carl McCunn.jpg
| caption                   = McCunn in what is believed to be one of his last photos
| birth_date                = {{birth date|1947|01|25|mf=y}}
| birth_place               = [[Munich]], [[Allied-occupied Germany|Germany]]
| death_date                = {{circa|{{Death date and age|1981|12||1947|01|25|mf=y}}}}
| death_place               = [[Brooks Range]], [[Alaska]], U.S.
| body_discovered           = February 2, 1982
| occupation                = Photographer
| parents                   = Donovan McCunn
}}
'''Carl McCunn''' (January 25, 1947 – late 1981) was an American [[wildlife photography|wildlife photographer]] who became stranded in the [[Alaska]]n wilderness and eventually committed suicide when he ran out of supplies.

==Early life and education==
McCunn was the son of Donovan McCunn and Erika Hess. He was born in [[Munich]], Germany, where his father was stationed by the [[United States Army]]. He was raised in [[San Antonio]], Texas, graduated from high school in 1964, and enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] shortly after dropping out of [[Community college#United States|community college]]. McCunn served in the Navy for four years and was discharged in 1969. He briefly lived in [[Seattle]], Washington, before settling in [[Anchorage]], [[Alaska]], in 1970.<ref name=AP-ds/><ref name=AP-sbs>{{cite news |url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/?a=d&d=SBS19821223.1.19 |title=Diary of death: One man's fight for survival |date=December 23, 1982 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=San Bernardino Sun |accessdate=March 25, 2020}}</ref>

==Alaskan excursion==
{{Location map|Alaska|lat_deg=68.683|lon_deg=-144.419|relief=1|width=300|float=left|caption=Location of McCunn's final campsite in [[Alaska]]}}
{{quotebox |text=I keep thinking of all the shotgun shells I threw away about two months ago. Had five boxes and when I kept seeing them sitting there I felt rather silly for having brought so many. (Felt like a war monger.) So I threw all away ... but about a dozen ... real bright. ... Who would have known I might need them just to keep from starving? |author= — Carl McCunn |source=diary excerpt<ref name=AP-sbs/><ref name=UPI-82/> |width=20em}}
McCunn had lived five months on the [[Brooks Range]] in 1976. In March 1981, he hired a [[bush pilot]] to drop him off at a remote, unnamed lake approximately {{convert|225|mi|km}} northeast of [[Fairbanks, Alaska|Fairbanks]], approximately {{cvt|40|mi}} west of the [[Coleen River]] and {{cvt|150|mi}} north of [[Fort Yukon, Alaska]],<ref name=Capps-821110/><ref name=Kaniut/>{{rp|174}}{{efn|McCunn's camp also has been reported as being near the confluence of the [[Coleen River|Coleen]] and [[Porcupine River]]s,<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7KU8FY14MR0C&pg=PT40 |title=Ghost: The true story of one man's descent into madness and murder |author=Puit, Glenn |publisher=Berkley (Penguin Group) |location=New York, New York |date=January 2011 |isbn=978-1-101-48597-2}}</ref> based in part on McCunn's estimate he was {{cvt|75|mi}} northwest of Fort Yukon.<ref name=AP-sbs/>}} on the southern margin of the Brooks Range. McCunn intended to photograph wildlife for about five months.<ref name="AP">{{cite news
|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/19/us/left-in-wilds-man-penned-dying-record.html |url-access=subscription
|title=Left in Wilds, Man Penned Dying Record
|agency=[[Associated Press]]
|date=December 19, 1982
|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]
|accessdate=April 23, 2008}}</ref><ref name=AP-ds>{{cite news |url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/?a=d&d=DS19821216.2.62 |title=Tragedy in frozen north: Victim writes own death diary |agency=AP |date=December 16, 1982 |newspaper=The Desert Sun |location=Palm Springs, California |accessdate=March 25, 2020}}</ref> On this trip, he flew in with 500 rolls of [[Photographic film|film]], {{convert|1400|lb|kg}} of provisions, two rifles, and a shotgun. Believing he would not need them, he prematurely disposed of five boxes of shotgun shells in the river near his camp.<ref name=UPI-82/> He began his stay entranced by the local wildlife, which was returning to its summer grounds.<ref name=AP-ds/>

Although McCunn thought he had arranged for a friend who was a pilot to return for him in August, he apparently had never confirmed this. McCunn had hired an [[air taxi]] service to fly him in and was expecting the friend to pick him up as he did not have enough money to pay for air taxi service out; however, McCunn compounded the error by never telling his friend he had hired the air taxi service to fly him to the remote location.<ref name="Kaniut">{{cite book
|url=https://archive.org/details/dangerstalksland00larr
|title=Danger Stalks the Land: Alaskan Tales of Death and Survival
|first=Larry |last=Kaniut
|year=1999
|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmil
trending_reason: The Carl McCunn article is likely trending on Wikipedia due to renewed interest in his tragic story of survival and the psychological complexities surrounding his final expedition in the Alaskan wilderness, particularly as discussions about wilderness ethics and mental health gain prominence.
